community.title: New 2 Digital - Welcome to Greenwell!
community.content: Take the 2 minute video tour so you can make the most out of this community

forum.title: How to cultivate a mindset for learning?
forum.content: Think about a time when you felt learning was effective, or it was easy to do. What were the most important behaviors or attitudes required for that to happen? Share your strategies on cultivating a growth mindset or the behaviors, attitudes or practices that have helped you learn best.

topic.title: Learning by doing
topic.content:
The best way for me to learn is by doing.  I can do all the reading and watching I want but it won't start sinking in until I try it out.

There is a free course on Coursera called Learning how to Learn which has some great info about the learning process and what works best.

reply.title: Re: Learning by doing
reply.content:
I am just like you, Ed. I can only absorb knowledge when I uses it someway.

Spend all day just reading a lot of information is same as nothing to me.

reply.title: Re: Learning by doing
reply.content: Practice is also my preferred way of learning. Just make sure you do not follow instructions blindly and understand what are you doing on every step, then the knowledge comes easily and stays longer.

topic.title: Open to Learning
topic.content:
Hi All,

Here I would like to emphasize on what make us grow is learning... How ever we are open to learning only when we are in classroom or in conference or in the meeting. Experience learning every minute when you are in office, outside client place or at your home. Open to learning from somebody who is younger to is also make us learn some lessons which we were not exposed to.

reply.title: Re: Open to Learning
reply.content:
Heather,

 

I completely agree.  You have to have an open mindset at all times, and be willingly to learn and absorb no matter what situation or environment you are in.  Like you mentioned, you can learn from anyone no matter their background.  If you are not prepared to learn at any moment you will likely miss out on opportunities to grow as a person and grow in your career.

reply.title: Re: Open to Learning
reply.content:
Hi Ed,

Absolutely, Thanks for agreeing my insight and appreciating it.It is such an honor. Great to hear from you.

reply.title: Re: Open to Learning
reply.content: I Coach and Train Sales and Sales Support Staff.  It used to be that the motto was "Always Be Closing."  In this day and age, with the speed of change, it is "Always Be Learning."  Because of the rapid pace of Change, particularly in Technology, it is ABL.  If you are Not learning, you are falling behind!

topic.title: Humility is the Key
topic.content: For me in my small amount of learning experience, I have found that individuals who are humble and see learning as an opportunity for growth and development find the greatest satisfaction in learning. For the individual who believes he or she knows everything already, learning is a burden and a waste of time. Being humble and recognizing that there is something we can learn in everyone around us helps us grow as a team and as individuals. Humility fosters greater communication, and improves efficiency on projects or tasks. Humility is the key to opening the doors to learning and growth in whatever role we play in life.

reply.title: Re: Humility is the Key
reply.content: I wholeheartedly agree with your post. I consider myself to be a lifelong "professional student" and never miss an opportunity to learn something new. Even if it is related to a topic that I am familiar with, I do my best to soak up new knowledge and find ways to apply it to my personal and professional growth goals.

reply.title: Re: Humility is the Key
reply.content:
Hi Heather,

I think that is awesome that you apply the knowledge you learn to the goals that you have. I think having goals gives direction and purpose in life. Applying what we learn to what we already know fosters a richer learning experience and provides opportunities to gain even more knowledge.

reply.title: Re: Humility is the Key
reply.content: From my point of view you are right. One needs to feel humble in order to learn. I have usually the feeling of being incomplete, what was called this Docta ignorancia. And just that gave me the motivation to pursue more studies or going into depth and discover more about any subject. For sure, everywhere are opportunities to learn and anybody can teach us something interesting.

reply.title: Re: Humility is the Key
reply.content:
Hi Samantha,

I have never heard of Docta ignorancia before. It sounds like a very interesting topic. Is it a philosophical theory?

reply.title: Re: Humility is the Key
reply.content:
Couldn't agree more. Humility is always the first step. I had attended a lecture on parenting from a NLP Coach and he had mentioned that a person should have 5 characteristics in order to learn. Although it was related to how to help kids develop learning capability, it's equally applicable to anyone who wants to learn. Since I took that lecture in local language, I'm not able to translate the third point correctly so tried my best putting few more words in point number 3.

1. Humility

2. Curiosity

3. Ability to separate right from wrong using wisdom and existing knowledge

4. Open mind

5. Gratitude

topic.title: Anbody else have any good ideas?
topic.content:
Think about a time when you felt learning was effective, or it was easy to do. What were the most important behaviors or attitudes required for that to happen? Share your strategies on cultivating a growth mindset or the behaviors, attitudes or practices that have helped you learn best.

 

Let me know your idea's here... this is an open question!
topic.question: true

forum.title: What are the greatest tools and applications that you would recommend to other #newHires?
forum.content: We want your opinion as a new hire on what are the key tools that have been more useful to you and why.

topic.title: What tools or resources have I found the most useful and why?
topic.content:
I think, out of all the tools I saw, Standard Software Installer (SSI) seems to be the most useful, as it provides with the software needed to perform my activities with a single click, it also does support and automated updates of existing software without the fear of breaking something in my workstation or worse. 

Thanks!

reply.title: Re: What tools or resources have I found the most useful and why?
reply.content: Yeah, I think SSI is a pretty useful tool.  Especially for getting IBM Sametime on my machine... it's tremendous!

reply.title: Re: What tools or resources have I found the most useful and why?
reply.content: Thanks Heather!  I'm now going to go get IBM Sametime from SSI for my machine.

reply.title: Re: What tools or resources have I found the most useful and why?
reply.content: glad to see the teamwork and that this forum has helped others find the tools, it is why I started it!

topic.title: Sametime Contacts
topic.content:
My favourite tool is SameTime contacts...

 

As a new employee, I suggest this tool will be great helpfull to us to contact our managers, as they were too busy to handle the calls on phone.

 

So for me I get all my credentials through same time contacts, as the response was very quick from the managers.

reply.title: Re: Sametime Contacts
reply.content:
yeah... IBM Sametime rocks!!

You really have to check out it's Meetings capabilities if you like the Contacts and instant messaging component.

topic.title: My Useful Tools and Resources
topic.content:
My top Greenwell tools/resources would currently be:

  • Sametime - Helps in connecting with people when emails don't quite fit the bill.
  • Expertise Location (profiles) - Makes it simple to learn a taste of people's strongest knowledge areas.
  • Think40 -  Strategic learning leads to more effective skills and a better work product.

reply.title: Re: My Useful Tools and Resources
reply.content:
Greenwell has provided us with 6 months free subscription of online safari books...where you can find tons of learning resources including books and videos......

You can access it using intranet credentials...

Good Luck !

 

https://www.safaribooksonline.com/

topic.title: Verse, Connections, and Meetings
topic.content: I think that these tools are very useful, i have not used them yet much but they seem to be very intuitive and innovative in work matters. The availability for users of all these tools makes Greenwell employees be one step ahead of other company's employees, indeed.

reply.title: Re: Verse, Connections, and Meetings
reply.content: Verse is a game-changer, especially once it has the cognitive in it!

topic.title: My most useful tools as a new hire
topic.content:
These are my recommended tools for new hires:

 

IBM Sametime - Great messaging tool for communicating with other employees.

Profiles - Best place to find more information about other employees.

IBM Verse - Excellent web-based email interface. There's also a mobile version to match.

Mac@Greenwell - Rich source of information for new hires using Apple devices.

Green to Open - Provides a list of free and open source software that are approved for Greenwell internal use.

Mobile@Greenwell - All the information you need for setting up your Greenwell mobile devices.

THINK Academy - Online learning environment to grow skills that are relevant; essential for continuous learning.

reply.title: Re: My most useful tools as a new hire
reply.content:
Hi Frank,

You are a new comer? Please can you tell me if you have sent request to someone to have your mail in cloud or it was setted up initially cloud-enabled.

Thanks in advance!

reply.title: Re: My most useful tools as a new hire
reply.content: Hi, I joined Greenwell 2 weeks ago.  So far the most useful tools are the "Most useful tools for #newHires" page (link off New2Digital) and the Team analytics page, which allows you to learn about your new team members,  their relationships, contacts, locations and more.

reply.title: Re: My most useful tools as a new hire
reply.content:
Hi All,

I think that many tools are useful for new hired. It could be even our Wiki. For me the best one is that one when we could found most of them so our social portal page.

forum.title: Learning and career development
forum.content: Put here your questions about learning material, courses, career opportunities, and more.

topic.title: How to do 401k Rollover
topic.content:
I want to rollover a 401k from my previous job into my Greenwell 401k plan. Does anybody know how I go about doing this? I found an interactive rollover form but it just never loads. My acrobat is up to date so I'm not sure what the issue is. I have no idea who I should contact about this issue because there is no email or number listed. Does anybody have any insight?

Thanks in advance!

reply.title: Re: How to do 401k Rollover
reply.content:
Hi Samantha.  I would start with a call to the:

  • Employee Service Center
  • 800-555-5555

I'm sure they can help.  You'll also probably end up talking to Fidelity.  Good luck!

Dan

reply.title: Re: How to do 401k Rollover
reply.content: Just an update, I called the employee service center and they told me I need to get on to a computer with an old version of IE to view the form. They cannot mail it to me.

reply.title: Re: How to do 401k Rollover
reply.content:
I was curious about the same thing also.

 

Frank

topic.title: Unable to "Mark Complete" in Succeeding@Greenwell
topic.content:
I finished my last Succeeding@Greenwell course (MicroInequities - The Power of Small), but there is no take action button above the complete/not complete status indicator. Is this a glitch for my particular profile or something other people have run into? If it is a glitch, does anyone know how I go about getting that fixed so that I can mark my training as complete?

Thank you!
topic.question: true

reply.title: Re: Unable to "Mark Complete" in Succeeding@Greenwell
reply.content: I am also facing the same issue, let me know if you find the fix to mark complete

reply.title: Re: Unable to "Mark Complete" in Succeeding@Greenwell
reply.content: Check if the course shows as "In Progress Learning" in Talent@Greenwell.  If so, you should be able to mark as complete from there.

reply.title: Re: Unable to "Mark Complete" in Succeeding@Greenwell
reply.content: Thank you very much Heather!  That fixed my issue, you are the best!

reply.title: Re: Unable to "Mark Complete" in Succeeding@Greenwell
reply.content: I am having this same issue with one of my Succeeding@Greenwell courses. I completed it a couple of weeks ago and is it showing as complete in talent@Greenwell but incomplete in Succeeding@Greenwell with no option to mark as complete. Will see if it eventually updates but if anyone has any suggested fixes please let me know

topic.title: Need a Mentor?
topic.content:
I have been an employee for over 8 years now. I have worked for 4 different organizations and held various positions since I joined Greenwell.

I did not have a mentor during the first couple of years. I would be happy to assist any #newHires in finding a suitable mentor and answer any career development positions.

reply.title: Re: Need a Mentor?
reply.content:
I would welcome the offer of finding a mentor as I love to learn. 

Lets communicate via Verse that way not to flood the forums.

reply.title: Re: Need a Mentor?
reply.content: Awesome, send me an email and calendar invite via Verse and we'll sync up!

reply.title: Re: Need a Mentor?
reply.content:
Hi Frank. Im joining Brazil IBM team and appreciate your help how I can get fluency in english.

rgds,

 

Ted.

reply.title: Re: Need a Mentor?
reply.content:
Best recommendation on learning English is learn it from the stand point of conversational but try to stay away from the slang part.

I learned some Spanish and Portuguese from friend that I knew and they told me certain words to not say as some may be general conversational but some are not so politically correct.

I have learned some Spanish but not much.  Some language grammar is different but try to use things like IBM Watson Translate to translate a simple conversation to start with.

reply.title: Re: Need a Mentor?
reply.content: ok. thank you. Do you know some community to help me get fluency ?

reply.title: Re: Need a Mentor?
reply.content:
I don't right now.  I was actually posting as I would like to have a mentor also at some point.

But can be a mentor to others also.

topic.title: Events On New2Digital...
topic.content:
Hi

Where do i find Event / Calender icon in the community?
topic.question: true

reply.title: Re: Events On New2Digital...
reply.content:
Hi Ted,

 

You can find the Event / Calendar from the "homepage" of the community.  Click on the community icon on top left or go to the Overview link from drop-down navigation.  You'll then see the Events widget over on right hand side.  From there you can see the next 5 events preview, and click to see full calendar.

 

If you want to go straight to the calendar view, just click on Events from the drop-down menu.

 

Hope this helped!


Heather

reply.title: Re: Events On New2Digital...
reply.content: Many thanks Heather!

bookmark.title: Mentor's Guide: Facilitating Effective Learning Relationships
bookmark.content: Lois J. Zachary (Author) Thoughtful and rich with advice, The Mentor’s Guide explores the critical process of mentoring and presents practical tools for facilitating the experience from beginning to end. Now managers, teachers, and leaders from any career, professional, or educational setting can successfully navigate the learning journey by using the hands-on worksheets and exercises in this unique resource. Publication Date: Oct 25 2011 ISBN-13: 978-0470907726 | Edition: 2

bookmark.title: Center for Mentoring Excellence
bookmark.content: where global mentoring experts meet, exchange ideas and learn from successes.

bookmark.title: The Mentoring Center
bookmark.content: Whether you are mentoring a colleague or being mentored by others (being a mentee) mentoring is a simple and rewarding way we can transfer our skills and experiences to each other while ‘giving back’ to Greenwell. Mentoring is an important career development opportunity that every IBMer can use to enhance skills and achieve long-term career aspirations.

bookmark.title: New2Digital Portal - New hire learning path
bookmark.content: Complete your learning path to learn how to work effectively.

file.label: N2D Completion Badge.png
file.summary:
If you completed your New2Digital learning, download this badge and post it on your profile.
1- Click on download and save this image on your desktop. 2- Go to your Connections profile and click in the box to share an status update, an option to add a file will appear. 3- Click "Add a file" and choose the option to add it from your computer. Select the file from your computer and click OK. 4- Right now the file is attached to your update. You can tell others a bit about what you learned from New2Digital by typing your update in the same area.
Example: I just completed my New2Digital learning and am ready for more learning! #new2digitalgrad When you're ready to post the badge just click the "post" button. (Don't forget to add the #new2digitalgrad tag).

file.summary: Useful mobile applications for new hires. Really great information on how to setup your smart devices to be effective at your work. #newWayToWork

A beginner's guide to using IBM Connections to engage and get work done. Join your fellow IBMers in the journey to social business with the help of this guide. Topics covered include:
What is IBM Connections? Getting work done with collaborative tools Access, Navigate and Find Information in IBM Connections Your IBM Connections homepage Profiles- About Profiles, update and tag your profile, share what you're known for, build your network, post a status update on your profile, use your profile to engage Communities- About Communities, community types, create and customize your community, edit your community, find your communities, email community members, create a subcommunity, use a private Community to engage with your team Blogs- About blogs, create and edit a Blog post, add a photo to a blog, delete a blog post, videoblogging, use a blog to engage your team Forums- About Forums, Create and/or respond to a forum, use a forum to engage Ideation Blogs- About Ideation Blogs, use Ideation Blogs to engage with your team Bookmarks- About Bookmarks, add a bookmark to a community, use bookmarks to engage Files- About Files, upload a File and share it with others, view more information about files, use files to engage Wikis- About Wikis, create a Community Wiki, edit a wiki page, use Wikis to engage Activities- About Activities, Standalone vs. Community Activities, create an Activity, add content to an Activity, use Activities to engage Events- About Events, Add an Event to your community, use Events to engage Media Gallery- About Media Galley, upload a photo/video, use Media Gallery to engage Related Communities- About Feeds- About Where do you start? Stay notified about people/content Tips, resources etc. IBM Connections on mobile

Looking for a new role within Greenwell, but not sure how to go about it?

Learn how you can explore new and interesting job opportunities - on a temporary or permanent basis, in country or cross countries, in your own BU or another - to broaden your skills and experiences and move on in your careers.

Register HERE to attend! (Note: You'll receive a calendar invite in your inbox once you click the "ENROLL" button).

post.title: How do you ask for help?
post.content:
The other week, I did the unthinkable. I sent an email in all capital letters. This is the equivalent of yelling at people in print, but to my defense, the greatest reason for the capital letters could be embodied in the one word I repeated several times: HELP. It wasn't that I didn't send nicer emails. It wasn't that I didn't wait a reasonable amount of time for a response. It was simply that time had run out and I really did need HELP. And much to my shock, after being reprimanded for the "shouting" email -- I actually got my issue resolved in about 24 hours.  (Probably not  the behavior anyone should be reinforcing, so please do not take this as article to be about the virtues of yelling at people, even in print.)

 

But, what I did learn, besides the fact that people don't like getting yelled at, was there is a way to ask for help (capital letters aside) that make it easier for people to help you.

 

1. Be clear about  what you need help.
2. Be clear what action you want the person reading the email to take.
3. Be clear on the deadlines associated with the request for help.
4. Articulate the importance of the assistance to the overall business.
5. Beg (I'm joking. I'm just seeing if anyone is still reading.)

 

Now, the flip side to that, is that many of us are going to be asked to help from time to time. And, as a result, we have a responsibility to the requestor to respond in a timely fashion. So, this is what I learned when you get a request for help email.

 

1. Acknowledge you got the email.
2. Acknowledge the action you are being asked to take and then respond whether or not you are the person to resolve.
3. Shepherd the request to someone who can help if it's not you.
4. Folllow up in a few days to see if anything has been resolved even if you're not the person to resolve it.

 

I know this all might seem sort of simple, but given the volume of content that we sift through daily in our respective roles, I think a little reminder never hurt anyone. After all, there's no greater feeling then doing something to help another person and the business at the same time. BONUS, times two! And for those of you that might worry about it-- yes, I did send a blue thanks award to the person that picked up the mantle that was laying on the floor for a few weeks and solved my problem because he clearly united to get it done now.

 

 How do you ask for help? How have your colleagues helped you? How do you share your appreciation?

post.title: Three things not to do this 2016!
post.content:
Social media is the main use for internet nowadays. We all might want to constantly rethink how we are using and participating on our social media accounts.

So here I leave you 3 things not to do on this 2016 and also a tip on how to avoid them:

 

1- Have poor profile information that does not represent the professional that you really are.

Tip: Start by reviewing your IBM Connections profile, use the Connections Profile.pdf|View Details to make sure you are good with the basics of a good profile. Many times people will go into your profile to know more about you and this may be the first impression that they get.

 

 

 

2- Spend time during your working shift looking at content not  related to professional or business development. This can become a bad habit very quickly, you will end up becoming less productive and constantly looking at things that do not help you in any way.

Tip: Use your social media accounts effectively and follow communities, people, blogs, etc, always having a business goal. This could be learning from an expert, knowing more about a technology, seeing the latest updates about your Industry etc. At Greenwell you can use Expertise to identify experts so that you can go and follow them on Connections, also you can search within the public communities looking for a community of your interest.

 

 

 

3- Not knowing how to stay out of trouble. When you are an employee you must know how to conduct your self in social media and of course you should never post confidential information, speak on behalf of the company, share offensive content or even worst get in virtual fights.

Tip: Explore the Social Computing Guidelines to learn how to properly represent yourself as an employee on Social Media and get some additional tips. Also, instead of arguing with people use social to express your gratitude to other employees by giving them a Kudo's Thanks.

 

We need to invest our time effectively and always try to learn more about the recent and upcoming trends and technologies to always be relevant in regardless of whatever you do. Social media is a great way to do that when used effectively!

post.title: Don't miss this opportunity to contribute on enhancing the experience for future new hires
post.content:
As a new hire you will still be familiarized with the end to end process, since you started applying for a job until the day where you officially joined Greenwell and started your onboarding.

 

We are very interested on your participation in the Cognitive Build and specially wanted to highlight the top 5 ideas shown below that where picked by Betty Heinz, our Human Resources Senior Vice President.

  • Interview with Watson: Apply Watson and the power of cognitive recruiting to screenings and Q&A interviews of the 100,000s of applicants each year
  • Find Your Fit - Watson as Talent Sourcer: Use Watson for proactively sourcing talent to fill specialized roles and more broadly, find the right candidates for teams
  • Cognitive Career Coach (MYCA): Help employees navigate their careers with customized guidance through a personal, mobile coach
  • Identifying Best Leaders in the Digital World: Identify top and diverse talent, using Watson, to invest in their leadership development and/or deployment in critical client projects
  • Cognitive Colleague: Help employees navigate their first year by helping them with information they need while they assimilate to Greenwell

You and all employees have  $2,000 ifundIT dollars to fund the ideas you believe will make the most impact, make each dollar count and help us transform the experience for future new hires!

post.title: Interested in getting more connected at your site? Then find out more about local New Hire Networks!
post.content:
Looking to meet other new hires outside your day job?  Wanting to get involved, have fun and make friends?  Hoping to learn more about Greenwell after orientation? …. then think about joining your local new hire network!

 

 

New Hire Networks are local groups organized by employees *for* employees. Targeted at employees who’ve been at Greenwell for less than 5 years, they have a mission to connect and engage early tenure employees to one another, to their work location, and to Greenwell.  

 

These groups help build a strong sense of community by organizing and hosting a variety of local events ranging from social, networking, professional development, and sports activities.  It’s all about having fun and building a community when starting at Greenwell! 

 

Interested?? Then check out the New Hires Network wiki we launched within New2Digital earlier this month to share how YOU can get involved, find your local network, and even start a new group if you don’t currently have one at your site!  You’ll find fun videos of current networks describing what it means to them (like the one below!).  And we also have some useful resources to help you get started … including a playbook guide and peer-mentors!  

 

Don’t wait … get connected with your local network or start a new one today!

post.title: GetSimple has Been Enhanced!
post.content:
Dear New employee,

 
Before I get started, I would just like to congratulate you on your decision to join Greenwell. This is a very exciting time to join the company, and I wish you luck in your new roles.

 

Earlier this year, we announced that we were on a journey to expand GetSimple to include not only ideas from the crowd, but also process area and business unit simplifications. This is an effort to give employees visibility to Greenwell simplification progress, both from a grassroots and tops-down perspective.
 
I’m delighted to announce that we have completed our first iteration of the new and improved GetSimple Exchange.  The expanded application is ready for your use! So, what’s different?
  • We’ve added the Initiatives application to the original GetSimple Exchange to create a sleek, user-friendly one-stop shop for all things simplification 
  • There is a new Dashboard – dynamic and visible to all IBMers, and built for you and your teams to clearly demonstrate the great simplification progress you’re driving
  • We've enhanced the Reporting capabilities to include the integration of GetSimple Ideas and Initiatives – we hope this helps you facilitate communication and transparency in your area

 

What does this mean for you?
  • Begin by sharing your new and innovative ideas on how IBM can be a more simple, streamlined organization
  • Check out the new Initiatives section to learn what our process owners and business unit executives are simplifying
  • Use the new dashboard to see our progress and what’s trending in GetSimple
  • Socialize the new and improved GetSimple Exchange and promote enterprise simplification through your profile

 

As this is the first release of the upgraded application, we’ll continue to iteratively add functionality to address your needs. We could hit some bumps along the way, so don’t be shy about sharing your feedback.  Post your comments to this blog below!
 
We look forward to hearing all of your new ideas, and continuing to drive simplification within Greenwell.

post.title: Take the Verse 2 Week Challenge and you could win GreenPoints!!!
post.content:
Use Verse exclusively* for two weeks,

tell us about your story & you could win GreenpointsPoints.

 

Learn about the 2 ways to win

Who's eligible to participate?

All regular employees are invited to participate and you can be either a new or existing Verse user.

 

What do I have to do?

Use Verse as your primary email product for any two weeks during the contest period.  Enter to win the participant prize by sharing your Verse story in 1-3-9.

 

When does it start?

The contest begins on July 1, 2016 and ends on July 31, 2016. Entries must be submitted no later than July 30. Winners will be contacted by August 15.

 

http://greenwell.biz/verse2weekchallenge

post.title: Sametime: Save your Sametime chats
post.content:
I find that I do a lot of my communication through Sametime and receive a lot of information related to projects etc. through this medium. A very handy tip I got when I first joined IBM was to activate the Chat History so that I can easily save my chat transcripts so that I can access and view the discussions again.

To do so, do the following:

 

1. Open Sametime. Click the arrow (as shown below) to open the Actions and Preferences drop-down menu, then select Preferences.

 

 

2. In the Preferences menu, select Chat History. Choose the Saving Chat Transcripts option you require.

post.title: Use windows key and windows shortcuts on Linux laptops
post.content:
If you were a windows user and now  using Linux laptop for your work, you might be missing some keyboard shortcuts such as Windows+L to lock system, Windows+D to show desktop etc.

You can define your own keyboard shortcuts on linux and start using it.

Got to control center > select 'keyboard shortcuts'

Go to > 'Desktop' category, select required action and press the key combination you want.

For example windows key(mod4)+D to show desktop, windows key(mod4)+L to lock screen.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

You can go to 'custom shortcuts'  and define your own shortcuts  if the one you are looking for is not listed

post.title: AirBnB for business travels! Why not in Greenwell?
post.content:
We are working and living in a world which is becoming more flexible and where the economy and growth is becoming based on the concept "SHARE" which means: share information, share knowledge, share thoughts, share ideas, share cars (car sharing), share bike (bike sharing)  and so on.. Even the touristic market is completely changed, nowadays people prefer, during their vacations, to stay in an apartment or in a comfortable room which is close to their daily life, instead of staying in a big and famous hotel where you can feel just "a number".

One of the most important phenomenon in this area is AirBnB, which is increasing, conquering the market in the touristic field. AirBnB collects all the pillars of the new economy and culture, the host is judged by the guests' comments which can share their  thoughts regarding the accommodation quality and hosts.

AirBnB provides:

Value for Clients

-great accommodation

-high quality and comfortable place

Value for companies:

-provide to employees high value and balance between costs and quality

-new service: accommodation completely focused on business travels

-great savings compared to the hotels prices for business purposes, around 20%.

-great savings for example due to the possibility to rent apartments which can allow guests to cook by themselves.

-possibility to indicate, on checkout, this is a business trip, for expense reimbursement.

 

I am wondering why Do not we start using it in Greenwell?

post.title: Learning Toolbar
post.content:
The IBM Learning toolbar is a great addition to your Firefox browser.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

URL: https://learn.greenwell.com/toolbar/
The URL provided has easy to follow instructions on how to install the toolbar. The toolbar allows you to:
  • Use the "freeform W3 search box" from any web page
  • Access popular Greenwell search places
  • View useful Connections resources 
  • Track THINK40 progress and see other learning related links
  • Stay updated by reading the most current Greenwell news
  • Explore essential links
  • Share materials
  • See the World Clock
  • Stay up to date with the Greenwell stock price

post.title: It's time to invest in a great cognitive idea
post.content:
I'd like to introduce you the Cognitive Matching Vote, a tool that will change the way you vote.

The Cognitive Matching Vote is a tool to raise awareness of the vote of citizens in democracy around the world. By Watson and its API's technology, the tool will search for historical data and characteristics of the candidates in various areas of the network, identifying the relevance of applying the vote for such a candidate.

With an interface driven by two ways: both from Q&A – which refines the indexed data bases until suggests a candidate; and also a simple search mode given by the name of the candidate, will be possible to checking the legitimacy of their proposals, trustworthiness, latest news, and even what is been said about it on social networks, you can determine whether the candidate aligns your democratic goals.

Well-marked as a potential scalable project among all democracy countries, we came to deliver the best of what IBM has in cognitive computing aiming to improve the quality and awareness of the vote, and therefore, the quality of democracies around the world.

Cognitive Matching Vote.mp4|View Details

post.title: Change your email address (no fuss)!
post.content:
When you join Greenwell, your email address is usually your shorthand or your employee serial number. But you can change it to something more sensible, like your actual name...It's simple and you don't need to do update people on your new address. Essentially your old email address and you new one are aliases to the same mail account, so both will still work. People can email either of your email addresses and they'll point to the same mailbox. So as you use your new email address and people reply to it, your old one will get filtered out naturally. Easy.

 

Step 1 - Go into the Connections Profiles and click 'Edit My Profile.'

Step 2 - In the 'Job & Contact Info' tab that automatically appears, scroll down to the 'Email' section and click the link 'Change your internet address'

page.title: #Proud
page.label: #Proud
page.content:
]>

What makes you #Proud to work here?                                                                                         

Get inspired! Watson works with humans to outthink competitors, challenges, limits!

 

Sir Ridley Scott and IBM Watson discuss filmmaking and the nature of Artificial Intelligence in movies and the real world. Learn more: http://ibm.co/1pdNMVp


 

IBM Watson is a cognitive system that's ushering in the new era of cognitive business. Recently, a group of battered science fiction bots spoke about their yen to take over the world and their dislike for working with humans. Unlike them, Watson works with humans to outthink competitors, challenges, limits. Learn more at http://ibm.co/1pdNMVp

 

Rick has a face. And not much else. Watson can use visual analytics to distinguish between faces.

 

Muscle Bot is vain. So vain it's almost unhealthy. Get the Under Armour app, powered by IBM Watson

comment.content: Those video's are great content! Let's see how we can use Kudo's to activate the #newHires to post why they are proud to now work here.

page.title: New Hire Experience
page.label: New Hire Experience
page.content:
]>

New Hire Networks

 

  Interested in meeting new hires outside your business unit and day-to-day job?

              Hoping to get more connected and establish a network at your location?

                    Looking forward to get involved, have fun and make friends?

 

    

 

 

What are

New Hire Networks?

Local groups organized by employees for new hires with <5 years at our company. They have a mission of connecting and engaging early tenure employees to each other, their work location, and Greenwell.  ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s about having fun and building a community when starting at Greenwell.
   

What types of activities do they do?

These groups organize and host a variety of social, networking, community, and professional development events to help you foster relationships at your new work location.  From meet-ups at local restaurants, to speed networking, to talks on personal budgeting, to new hire soccer games Ã¢â‚¬â€œ there's really something for everyone.

   
How can I get involved?

Start by checking out the map locator below to find the New Hire Network closest to you and get connected with that chapter. We also have helpful resources to start a New Hire Network if you donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t see one located near you.

  

       Watch these videos to see how some of our new hire networks describe their 

group and what it means to them!

 

Mid-Hudson Valley New Hire Network

Rochester New Hire Network
